3-HPHmzylxe7nKs5sFpPBg.text: This was the worst restaurant I have ever been to. They were extremely rude. If you have a nut allergy DO NOT GO HERE. There menu says to let them know if you have an allergy and when I told them they got extremely upset and told me that I can't eat anything here as everything is cooked in peanut oil. You think this would be something they say up front outside their restaurant or on the menu. What the point of telling them you have a nut allergy if you can't even eat anything there? This restaurant was a waste of my time.

YkCUkYzqxsjsBq-Lq0yAJg.text: Very popular already and rightly so. This small, utilitarian Sichuan/Szechwan cafe over 2 or 3 floors serves up spicy and pungent dishes from Chengdu that can be budget-busting cheap as long as you've got cash in your wallet (they don't take cards). Don't expect comfy seats or generous tables, and do expect to be surrounded by Chinese students and fighting for elbow room.We hit the 30 pounds mark with a dinner for two of two ice teas (meh), one boiled rice, fried green beanstalks with crispy stuff (yum), a slow-cook stew of beef and knotted tofu (delicious) and a gargantuan bowl of chilli-oil, chilli and sichuan pepper cooked catfish which arrive looking like a potential torture device from a James Bond move...So Mr Bond... you think your face can survive being immersed in the hot oil bath of 300 chillis and 200 peppercorns...? Mwa hahaha hahaWhile not good for the wasteline, the fiery oily catfish was music to my tongue and lips. Tingling the nerve ends on entry and warming my cockles after each bite. A steal at the current promotion price of 7 quid for the bowl. The beef and tofu dish was even better, with tingles of peppercorns and a juicy salty gravy.While we loved the food and wished we could've explored much more of this exotic menu, we did leave parched from the quite stupendous spicy saltiness of sichuan food. Staring at another table's cucumber salad had me practically swooning as I left in an emergency hunt for milk tea, frozen yoghurt and iced lime cordial.

80Icbbz6VvSwJ-rsvo-gGg.text: The menu had creative offers, but we were disappointed by the quality, perhaps we could have made better choices.

9yi3I71pnTOhLFmcrVdvsg.text: Cheap Chinese food with Communism propaganda (you know it's real when you've got the triple C's).  Upstairs and downstairs space, surprisingly roomy and quiet for the Bar Shu sibling.  Dishes ranged from 3 to 12 quid.Lamb with crispy rice wasn't so crispy, but the boiled egg custard, the cold chicken with mustard, pork belly, mapo tofu, and pea shoots were deliciously flavorful.  Dan dan noodles were okay, I've had more of a punch elsewhere.It's hard not to want to try the whole menu here, which is why multiple visits with lots of hungry stomachs are required.

nZBnpUyLQWdJ__01Dx9KKQ.text: Food was ok, ordered what looked like a wok dish, it was friend chicken and all hot peppers. was very fry and not very good. other chicken dish was good, but have never had peppercorns in a dish which the crunch was surprising.  Only takes CASH!!!

e3lmx_Z8fkdEjHZ7V4o5ig.text: Tried "Shui Zhu Yu", Yuxiang Pork & potstickers/pork dumplings.The potstickers were very impressive.They have the stuffing I've never had before. The pork tastes more like smoked. Very different.The fish is on special offer, only 8.9 pounds, which is definitely worth it.The Yuxiang Pork is also very authentic.Two of us with a total of 26.30, reasonable.

YhjOuNCuTu3YVIXwvJVlow.text: Very flavorful, more than what I expected. I like this place above all the Chinese restaurants I've been to in London. If you're not used to Szechuan cuisine, it might be a little unfamiliar, but if you like it, this is the go-to for Szechuan in London.

w8YttJmHEYUHiOGjpD-58A.text: This is the second time I went back to Baiwei for the fish in hot oil. It is an excellent dish and a very reasonable price point of 9 GBP. The portion is good too. I have seen people ordering two dishes of this fish!  The price does not include service charge. And this is another place that only accepts cash. The food is quite authentic so you see a lot of Chinese students' get-together here. However, last time we ordered sour green been with minced pork 酸豆角肉末, which was not quite up to standard

qSQj8L1nHcwDgCdSoVhwgQ.text: Not the friendliest, but I did come in 20 minutes before closing. That said, ribs in cumin--Ahmazing

N3_moZPqUwlXt4IDbESD_g.text: Good spot. The food is not inexpensive but it is pretty tasty and they don't skimp on portions. Ambiance-wise, this place is pretty bare-bones. We sat in the basement, which has a real bunker vibe going on. The spicy dishes are indeed spicy, so know that. Adequate service. Not a bad option but I'll try new places in Chinatown before coming back here.

p_6gOyhyh44WznJahacmXw.text: Maybe this is really authentic Chinese but in that case, I don't think real Chinese is for me. 4 of us dined, excited to be eating in a popular restaurant and all of us were disappointed. The dishes (chicken gao, tofu goa, and pork with peppers and black beans) tasted odd though for different reasons. The pork was mostly fat, the chicken was tangy and loaded with peppercorns and the tofu was just badly flavored. At £9 a dish and £2.50 for a can of coke, it's also overpriced. Service was fine though the tables are tiny and there's no place to really wait for a table.

QBZMqznYVyPTP_pojcwUXg.text: The food was really good. However, the service was awful. The waitresses were impolite and unhappy that made me feel depress...

r2IAK5w-YtMw8VGE6R1fgA.text: *BEWARE*Tourist trap. Came in to grab a quick bite. Ordered two meals, waiter says "there's a minimum per person" HUH? £10 per person. Dude, our food order was £18 for two people. "Not enough" So I added a beer. "Not enough, drinks are not included".  F  YOU  right... I'll spend my £ else where.

bOo6gW4BfgRwrviBMbFR0A.text: A huge vote of thanks to Rachel Z for organising a meal at this little gem of restaurant. Easy to miss on the edge of Chinatown, they have made the best of the small floor acreage spread over several floors. They were very helpful in re-arranging tables for our group of 6I must also give praise to the staff for their friendliness and helpfulness in helping guests unfamiliar with Sichuan food. They do speak good English to help navigate the menu. Their menus also deserve praise - large, well bound red tomes (in keeping with the decor but more about this in a moment) containing lovely pictures and descriptions of all their dishes. I love the quirky sense of humour in the restaurant with communist party propaganda posters adorning the walls taking me back to my trip to ShanghaiFortunately, we had a bona-fide connoisseur in Rachel Z and we just sat back and let her order. And she ordered up a veritable feast, which came to a very reasonable £20 a head - note that it's a cash only establishmentThe star of the show was the mao cei hotpot, one of their signature dishes. You select different ingredients to go into a fiery stew, which arrives dramatically in a huge claypot. Being Sichuan food, it's fiery hot from the many chillis that you can see but it's also the little peppercorns, which burst in your mouth and numb your tongue. I do however want to emphasise that the food is also packed with flavour as well as heat. This was our favourite dish of the eveningThis was a truly exhilarating meal. I had the funniest feeling when my mouth was fine eating the fiery food - I think the peppercorns had numbed my tongue enough that I could do so but obviously, my body was feeling the heat even if my mouth couldn't because sweat was pouring off my forehead, prompting Krista A to offer me a tissue! There was a whole wave of exhilaration among the group and later, we decided it could have been an endorphin rush in response to the heat! Not only did our stomachs feel sated but our pores also felt cleansed!Other dishes included catfish in hot chilli oil (soft and moorish), slow cooked pork belly (mmmm), green beans, fried greens in garlic and a mixed meat dishThis is what Chinese food in London in 2013 is all about. After decades of Cantonese classics, we're now in the brave new world of Sichuan, Hunan, Taiwan and Dongbei food. If they serve food as good as Baiwei, long may the revolution continue!!

photos.caption: Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Cao wei hotpot

_NaFuUafQtjpeGdlxUTqAQ.text: Amazing chinese food, good reviews here on yelp made our decision of going here for lunch our first day in London. Got sent up to the second floor and it was us two and alot of chinese people. Takes only cash not cards. Will so go back here next time.

I4uEKFbuW466eoYMW-z7dg.text: That Baiwei has kept fake-me-out Chinese food off its menu makes it my new favorite weekend joint Chinatown. Sweet and sour what? Not here.Solid start with chili oil pork ears, which erred on the side of pickle sweet of northern tradition; black pepper beef tripe was served cold and tender, pairing up real nice with their impossibly fluffy white rice.Szechuan beef brisket and bamboo stew arrived in a quaint little wooden bucket. Super flavorful, a sure favorite for those looking for a heavy flavor profile. Lunch wrapped up with the fried spicy pork knuckles: crispy skin and soft insides, all good things.Your order will arrive quickly, in my case all four in 5 minutes. That at least one waiter is dedicated to each dining floor makes calling one so much easier - a rarity in this part of town.Fair warning - only cash is accepted.

photos.caption: Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Szechuan fried pork knuckle
Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Spicy beef stew
Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Spicy pork ear

encZKTWL_Z5sz_cIbI2gRw.text: I loved this restaurant I came here when I was in London and had their spicy ribs and their hot and sour soup was excellent

UCjdUlUgeLrPIxSl4aIAKw.text: The place is tiny and the tables not much bigger, meaning that space is quite cramped both in your personal area and on the table. Considering the size of some of the sharing dishes particularly the soups. The flavours were great in some dishes, but the peppercorns that were in literally everything had a numbing effect on the tongue that almost felt like it was compensating for the heat of the meal. Thus the food didn't appear to taste that hot personally to me. My favourites were the braised pork belly. So tender. Followed by the Pork hotpot with onions, peppers and LOTS of peppercorn. Whilst the food was hot, everything was packed with flavour. The heat didn't overpower the flavours of the dishes which is a real positive. We all know that feeling where food is so hot nothing can satiate the fire. Not milk, or running your tongue under a cold tap. With the side affect being you can't taste the flavours of any food afterward. Food never reaches that point and as a result you can enjoy spicy dish after spicy dish with no issues.Service was nice and friendly. The only downside being the place doesn't take bookings and is cash only. But given the generous portions and free internal wamth during the winter months, who can really complain. It's difficult to squeeze groups into the small location too, so keep parties below 6 and preferable 2-4 and you'll be fine.

photos.caption: Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Belly pork
Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Thinly sliced pork with lots of chilli!

_EBAA8gu2eVHRpCK1WXTFg.text: Suggested by a chinese friend of us (she calls this place "mom kitchen" as she is from Chengdu), we had to try this chinese restaurant, where we were sure to find authentic chinese cuisine.And we wonderfully found it!!I never been to Sichuan, but I did live for more than one year in Shanghai, and I could get from the first impact this was some seriously honest chinese stuff: Small place, small tables with unmatched sizes table/chairs, rude service and continuous repetition of the rules "cash only cash only cash only".. Oooh, I do love you Baiwei!!Avoiding the hotpot for now (but I'll get back for it, granted!), we took a wide selection of dish, 6 for 3 people. Be prepared, you won't know most of the dishes, but just indulge on the pictures, then close the menu and open it n times, then point your finger to a dish and order it! You'll surely get something delicious in front of you!But beware, did I already say this is AUTHENTIC cuisine? That means you'll get two things in your food: garlic and peppers. Your food will be damn covered by it, as it is in a usual restaurant in the Middle Earth (Zhongguo)! And another notice, in comparison with the dishes you usually get in the european-washed chinese restaurant you are used to, dishes are much bigger, 2 per person may even be too much!Aaah Baiwei, you brought me tons of memories to my eyes, and at the end I don't know whether I was crying more from remembering the awesome time in China or the peppers!

wKeECyxONFbHXhUGQ2zF4A.text: Service sucks and it literally makes me think that living in London must be miserable, dishes that are supposed to be spicy only turned out to be really oily. I don't know why they have such a high rating... Then again this isn't the first time Yelp gave me a wrong impression of a restaurant here in London... Still don't understand why a restaurant with bad food and service could get a 4 star

XW-EWP0WWUzepaEj7M5akw.text: Very authentic.  I had the spicy eggplant.  Remember to order rice as it doesn't come automatically with the dishes.Very clean but small.

osZJF119beVJH5jAKp5mSA.text: I ate at this place when I was in London in mid-March and I liked it. The food reminded me of my mum's cooking, but it was a bit pricey -- like basically everything else in London. I ordered a noodle dish although the hot pot on the next table over looked pretty appetizing as well. The restaurant itself is small and intimate, and located in the heart of London's Chinatown. Definitely would recommend

CA0cD4j5UerRECqMH9rz5A.text: Among Top 10 London Chinese restaurants. Fiery and flavorful Schezuan cooking - unadulterated in any sense. Get the lamb w chillies, rainbow salad, catfish stew with pepper, eggplant salad and prawns with egg white. The rainbow salad is a spectacular umami bomb. Highly recommend.

-FyzqzilYHXISEZk5LpEbA.text: This is probably the best London Sichuan restaurant I have dined in so far. The food is definitely more on the authentic side...but, its actually NOT SPICY ENOUGH. Sure, the dishes are full of chili oil, peppers, peppercorns, but I only took two gulps of water the entire meal. So, this is definitely catering to the British crowd (I must admit I was raised in Shanghai & Southern California and an absolute lover of spicy food). I also thought other flavors just werent strong enough. Overall, everything was 'A-OK' - thus the 3-star.Me and my boyfriend were lucky enough to have the ground floor window seats, which is probably the best spot in the house. The table & benches are in the more traditional style where the table is much higher than the current norm.The CPC propaganda theme is a lil silly and gimmicky. It was estimated that Sichuan province had the highest cases of death from starvation during Great Leap Forward's famine...not sure how the posters are supposed to make me feel while eating all the food? Nevertheless, still better decor than the typical environment with woodwork, lanterns, awful paintings, and mirrors.

KVGpn7Dh8hTUIGTi1TtgnQ.text: Very authentic Sechuan kitchen. Loved it! Very spicey, if you plan to go out afterwards be advised you'll smell like what you just had :) But hey that's what authentic is all about. I can only recommend it

QyuiLwiA4Rnuzl6mIXwPlg.text: First time here and everything was absolutely awesome! Had lemongrass tea, hot and sour soup, beef and coriander dumplings, red braised duck, and fish fragrant pork slivers. Hot pots are super popular and will be coming back to try one, and maybe the chilli chicken dish.Love it!

8Mgaj-7XhuoM7MQfoplOVw.text: Wow - just wow. I've not had chili chicken like this since boat quay in Singapore! Everything we tried was really tasty. It's quite a small venue, but they have seating on the ground floor and 1st floor. Prices are reasonable for the quality of the food, and service was good.

S04jWSyMAPS6y-s157KzTw.text: After a bit of a disaster and having to walk out of a restaurant we had reservations at earlier in the evening, we were hungry and needed something good. So Andrew M. suggested we go to Baiwei after hearing Yee Gan's recommendation of the place. We all love Chinese (and I'm all about the spice), so it was a big hit for everyone.So we arrive, and we are told several times "cash only". It's a bit strange, although given how we like to use cards pretty much everywhere now, I suppose they need to make sure that people have the necessary cash to pay for the meal. We waited a bit to find out if they had a table for five, and they told us to go upstairs. Luckily, they had a great table for us, next to the window, and also a table where someone didn't have to sit in someone else's lap. So that was a good start. The menu looked pretty extensive as well with lots of choices available. We opted for a couple of appetizers and quite a few mains (we may have over-ordered), but the whole bill came to £29pp so it worked out well for us all.To start we had some sort of chicken dish and a tripe dish. The chicken was good, but not amazing, and weirdly had a lot of cartilage left in the meat. The tripe was fantastic though. I couldn't get enough. Not too chewy, lots of flavor and I was really impressed. For the mains, we ordered a selection, including a bucket of beef, and almost everything we had was delicious (and spicy). I was in heaven. The cumin lamb was probably my favorite with a nice cumin-y crust on the lamb and some delicious green chiles served with it. We also got some beef shin, and it was nice, but a little bit fatty and gelatinous, and one piece I bit into was pretty much only cartilage.But I'd come back. It was some of the tastiest Chinese food I've had in London, even if we didn't go too crazy with the selection of offal available. But no complaints at all. Even with it being cash only. I'm kind of craving that lamb right now....

YZjs_VvDMktXPjP_3ESOtA.text: This the definition of a "whole in the wall" which guarantees great food!  Fast service, great staff and the best Chinese food I have eat ever!

GFWkB9TdG_BjFlOhayCATA.text: Order a beef dish which was very tasteful. Very good and fresh vegetables. For £12 a person, it was worth it.

rD2EYSB38I8LSzEm8ZLQDQ.text: I've been to Baiwei four times now, and each time has been better than the last. The first time we went, despite the place being nearly empty, we were offered a seat right by the toilets. Not nice. The waitress was quite rude when we asked for a different table, too.But that seems to have been a one-off, and I'm pleased to say that since then, we've had brusque but efficient service, great food, and normal seating. Regarding seating, this place is crammed full. If your posterior is average or a little larger than average or you're particularly tall, you may have a difficult time getting comfortable when it's full--and it's almost always full.Cash only, as everyone has commented--and as the staff will remind you about three times. ;) But there's a cash point right down the street.The important part is, of course, food! This is really nice, really homey Sichuanese. It's not prettied up, it's not fussy, and it's all been delicious. We've munched our way through about 1/3 of the menu so far. Our favourite dish by far--we get it every time--is the golden coin beef tripe. It's a cold, spicy tripe dish and it's absolutely perfect, with numbing peppers throughout. The spicy dishes tend to be along the dry wok-fried end (and hot pots, we haven't tried one yet) while the mild dishes are more the goopy-sauce fare. We haven't liked them as much, though if you're scared of fire, the gong bao chicken is pretty tame and can be made without peppers. (But try them, they're delicious.)Mains are, I think, a little overpriced for the area and the décor (crammed in diner-style, basement if you're down there, knocking elbows and knees with neighbours). Appetisers are absolutely overpriced for tiny portions, so lean towards the mains.They don't take reservations and evenings get very full, but they do tend to have a brisk turnover. Aim for an early or late dinner and you should be ok.

LJJjcko2APjlIxS5qLqRQw.text: Authentic and amazing Chinese.  Forget your usual British-friendly Chinese dishes. This is hard-core Chinese eating.  It is very bright and you sit on small tables with stools but you come here for one reason--to eat great dishes.  We had a duck dish (duck on the bone) with vermicelli that was awesome.  I liked the aubergine dish as well.  Not a massive selection and not dishes I recognize but it was all about the spice and flavor.  They serve beer--that's it for alcohol and they don't take cards.  Best place to eat on a cold day--the spices will warm you up.

aTV8NZ6aANdMMFSAxidy4w.text: The hot pot is the best I've ever had! I always end up stopping at this little gem multiple times whenever I'm in  London.  Little tip, if you want an even more authentic culinary experience, ask for extra spicy and extra Sichuan peppercorns. I've seen them tone it down a little and it's much better with those extra peppercorns. My only complaint is that they're occasionally inconsistent. Sometimes the hot pot is mind-blowing (intensely fragrant and complex), other times just good, but not exactly at the same level.  Still, I cannot recommend this place enough (specifically for the hot pot as that's the only thing I ever get there). Don't expect this place to have super smiley table service. Respect that there's a cultural difference. I didn't perceive the service to be rude at all, just Asian! (I'm Asian, I'm allowed to say that). Not all the servers speak perfect English. So...this ain't like brunch at a vegan cafe in LA, you know what I mean? There's a vast difference between rude and just neutral, functional and quick.

BtMsf-Zi5Eht7YwtV8qD7Q.text: Nice and affordable Chinese place but careful IT IS CASH ONLYIt's the same style of place than Baozinn ( same owner I think). They are serving Sichuan food so perfect if you like spicy food!We ordered baozin, chili cabbage, and beef brisket with bamboo shoots and some white rice. It was good and very spicy!We had a nice time there but I think I prefer Baozinn for the meals proposed.

IITSE9BkbLv3XUnruQ1mGg.text: This place is A-OK indeed. I guess I was expecting there to be more vegetarian options, or at least be able to order something without the meat. In some cases it's possible, in others not. I was intersted to see how this place compared to the Chinese restaurants I've been to in China. That's really broad I know, but whatever. I remember there being a lot more vegetable options, but here there didn't seem to be as many. We ordered the Tofu Slivers as an appetizer which was actually one of my favorite dishes. They're essentially tofu noodles served cold and with a subtle brown warm sauce with chillis. It was really addicting and delicious. The hot and sour soup was very strange. Almost too strong of a brown sauce flavor. A little too much for me. The gong bao prawns with peanuts had a very strong ginger flavor which was nice. And the pock-marked old woman's tofu with pork (we got it without pork, which was a nice option) was a bit of a disappointment. It had 2 chilis on the menu so I thought it would be too spicy for me, but it wasn't really spicy at all. It also had a lot of oil and not much flavor unfortunately. The service was also very... cold, which could be part of the culture. Just be aware that they won't smile and if you want something you need to ask for it, they won't check on you. The restaurant seating on the ground floor is very small... and it's CASH ONLY!

photos.caption: Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Gong bao prawns with peanuts
Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Pock-marked old woman's tofu (without pork)
Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Tofu slivers

NLy7EBpc052h_SVuWi59uQ.text: Another good visit. The hot pot was again the star but they have really toned down the spiciness which is a disappointment. Kung pao chicken was also very good. Lastly, they will not let you order more food once you have ordered which is annoying.  Obviously, their main priority is turning tables, not customer service. You've been warned!

N7gtnu275hLGy4O20pOuwQ.text: Food here was amazing!!! If you like soups and spice, make sure to try the hot pot dish.  I also thoroughly enjoyed the thinly sliced beef with cucumber and pickles- the flavor is something I have never had before but delicious.

ITvWxaSft4-isyCVkE4_ig.text: The food was extremely tasty and very authentic feeling, but felt a little bit out of place as someone non-Chinese, which was in part due to the staff.Upon entering, we were told "cash only" (no hello, welcome, or other greeting). After saying that was fine, she said to go upstairs.We went up the narrow, steep staircase, and were greeted a second time with "cash only." After acknowledging this, she placed us in the corner table.The tables themselves are hard wooden stools. Chinese music is then playing overhead, and spoken all around (workers and customers alike). The server came over and looked put upon each time we ordered or requested something (including the bill).However, the food itself was fantastic, which made up for a lot. It's a bit expensive, though not necessarily unexpected for the area. If you're not familiar with the dishes, it's not a problem for ordering since there is a clear menu with pictures that you can order from.

photos.caption: Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Sizzling lamb with cumin
Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Second floor dining area

4XFw1xaJGalx-CriicYWUg.text: This was recommended to us by a Chinese friend - very authentic and good chinese food!It may take a little "getting used to" since it is not the typical Western-Style Chinese dishes, but well worth it! Best to order a couple of dishes and share :)!(Careful: "spicy" means "very very spicy")

photos.caption: Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. A bit of everything - fish soup, pork trotters, dumplings and duck!

HNoQZjFgqH3pYjSOoCzc3w.text: We walked in. Party of 5. Two many rules! No Credit Cards, 12Pound minimums per person. Walked out. Didn't eat!

SZqtCZFukwI6D8Cf8BIU0w.text: Baiwei gives you a little food journey to the northern areas of Chinese food including Sichuan and Shandong. Most of their dishes are spicy so I wouldn't recommend if you can handle your chillies. Although compared to Sichuan food in Sichuan, it is actually quite mild. Dishes are quite large portions and made for sharing so not really suitable for single diners either. The restaurant has upstairs and downstairs seating although tables are still very limited due to how small the place is. It is very nostalgic of my memories of China with it's dullness and  basic wooden stools and tables. Not a very romantic place to be honest. We were seated upstairs and service was surprisingly friendly and efficient so the atmosphere improved drastically then. Tables filled up very quickly, mostly by Chinese customers.Aubergine with preserved duck egg, red pepper and garlicA lovely cold salad to start with a very satisfying contrast in textures from the deep fried slippery buttery aubergines and the crunchy diced red peppers and cucumbers. The preserved egg gave it the strong saltiness that did get a little too salty for me especially combined with  the seasoning. Better to save it with rice. Still a very cool refreshing start before the spicy dishes comes inCatfish in spiced gravy with Shendong pancakesTwo butterflied catfish still keeping its slippery tenderness and flaky texture even though both sides have been fried then coated in a rich sticky gravy. It was slightly over seasoned but the complexity of the sauce with the sweet, savoury, umami and mild spices made it worthwhile, especially with rice. I was also too in awe how moist and tender the fish was yet packed with flavour. I also highly recommend immersing the pancakes in the gravy or at least soaking them so they take on some flavour, as well as making them pliable again as they were almost rock hard like they weren't freshly madeRed braised duck with konjakuA dish to avoid. They were really tight with the amount of duck. Most of it was little bits of broken bone. But we weren't missing out as the meat was so overcooked it was dry, dense and almost flavourless. The chilli soup it was immerse in was bland and lacklustre, lacking depth and complexity. It actually become helpful to reduce the saltiness of the catfish dish.Wasn't the best dish to serve it was konjaku either (people may know it was the zero-calorie noodle) that had no flavour of its own and just there with its rubbery bouncy texture. Wasn't very welcomed in the dish.Mr Xie's Dan Dan noodles with mince beefThe cheapest yet the best dish of the lot (£4.50). The portion is quite small, more a side dish than a meal of it's own being served in a rice bowl. The noodles were soft and bouncy and very fragrant in its egginess. It was in the perfect ratio of mince meat and gravy too, just enough to coat it in sauce and provide the stickiness for the well marinated mince meat to cling on. All very well seasoned and a piece of pak choi just to break up the stodginess.Although I didn't get to try a lot of the dishes offered I don't think it will be a place I returned to. Dishes were quite overpriced for what they were, £14.50 for the red braised duck that was barely edible or had much ingredients in there other the broth. Some of the dishes were too salty and almost all the dishes had room for improvement. The atmosphere doesn't exactly make up for it either. With so much competition in area I don't see this one lasting very long in Chinatown unless I managed to go on a bad day,

photos.caption: Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Menu
Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Menu
Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Menu

jo6Jt3H38AUcQjh1kMJvmw.text: The food was great, nothing negative. The reason for 1 star is their horrible service. Do not try to eat here since you would get stomachache under the bad eating environment. You have one hour to finish your meal and have to pay in cash.The owner of the restaurant dropped his name card in our dish without apologies and walked away directly. When I asked how he would like to deal with the situation, he replied rudely and didn't give any reasonable solutions. Also many of the 5-star reviews were made by agents. Please, think about it. Eating should be enjoyable and relaxed. Baiwei is absolutely not the wise choice!!!

klcDIHkWH700-m6ze_-Lpw.text: Not the easiest place for a Westerner with little knowledge about Chinese cuisine. Most of the food is spicy and there are lots of ingredients rarely found in Western kitchen. The staff didn't give any recommendations or explain the menu to us. We liked the food though.

photos.caption: Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Slow-cooked pork with mushrooms

hj9LIqFkqy2SOInhPEzVlA.text: Good experience. Ate here alone. It was really small and hot inside, but the food was great. Had the MaPo tofu and steamed dumplings.

4-L8M3KtqT3mFsSMX6UPgw.text: Warning: do go here before a night out because you will invariably eat too much and want to go into a food coma and you will knock any potential lovers out with your intense garlic breath. And besides, it's easier to get a table midweek. Food here is pretty flavoursome and not too gentrified. There is a lot of oil throughout but with clever ordering you can balance those oilier dishes out with cleaner, drier dishes. There is a lot of pork mince/beef mince sprinkled incorporated within the dishes like a garnish really. I'd say the highlights of this place involve a lovely combo of veg and meat such as the fish fragrant aubergine with pork and the pot of tofu with pork and don't forget the dried fried beans and pork (all mince). The menu sounds pretty hot but it's not too crazy. That being said, you probably won't have to ask for more chilli (unless you are hardcore). Make sure you get the snack cucumber as it compliments all of the dishes and share everything. Staff are so lovely here don't forget to add service. Oh and bonus! the toilets are super clean.

photos.caption: Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Really cute art on the walls
Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Seats downstairs!
Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Smack cucumber, fried bean and pork, tofu and pork, so much garlic

r5nw5VrUeh-gHdUQ6h7mDw.text: Not great service, but really excellent Sichuan dishes. Great place to go if you're looking for authenticity in your Chinese cuisine. Cash only, so be warned.

8PXVkxZmgPtEuTx_Duw92g.text: Ni hao!  Once again I love getting introduced to new amazing restaurants through yelp after seeing so many rave reviews.  I was finally able to take a nice long lunch on a Friday and definitely lived up to all the hype.Amongst 3 girls, 3 dishes was way too much food but glad we did.  We shared the- Dry wok double fried pork - It was spicy, the kind that makes you sniffle and sweat- Mustard sea bass - We tried to balance out the spice with this dish but it had a slight kick.  Regardless another really good choice- Aubergine with mince pork - This was a veggie side but I could've had the whole thing as a main with a bowl of rice.  A lovely hot and sour kick kick to it.I've been so good about not over eating and of course overstuffed myself... and still had left overs!  Go with a big group and order slightly less than 1 dish per person.  Definitely will be back to try some of the other dishes.

photos.caption: Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Mustard sea bass
Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Aubergine with mince pork
Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Dry wok double fried pork

S5zFDtnOYhKB-xNUnKk1_w.text: Baiwei means "a hundred flavours" in Chinese. It indeed offers many delicious flavours, but one is particularly dominating: spicy!A very promising new kid in the hood, Baiwei specializes in Sichuan cuisine. Through a seemingly narrow entrance, it actually occupies 3 floors (ground, upper level and basement). Quite a lot of seatings available. Not a huge fan of the propaganda theme, but the space is pretty clean and neat in general so I'm not complaining. On to the food. - Chengdu Mao Cai(成都冒菜):  It's very similar to a hotpot, the main difference is that it comes already cooked in a big clay pot. You can choose 3 types of meat/seafood and 3 vegetables from many. It came quickly with a side of sesame dipping sauce to balance off the heat. And man it was SO GOOD that towards the end of the meal some of us were still searching for the bits and pieces of anything remained in the pot.- Fatty beef in sour soup(酸汤肥牛): One of my favorite. The beef is thinly sliced and tender, the soup base is spicy with chili pepper and peppercorn,  sour from rice vinegar. The flavour dances on my tongue and it's the best with some rice on the side. - Spicy dry pot with twice cooked pork (麻辣香锅回锅肉): Another pot of mixed meat and veggies, but it comes stir fried instead of stewed. The flavour is good, however it had too many peppercorns mixed among the food. It's unfortunate because it numbs your tongue so quickly and you have to pick it out. One suggestion would be heat the oil with peppercorns first and get rid of them before putting the rest of the ingredients. Or choose the peppercorn strings on vine so it's easier to pick them out. - Fish in spicy oil (水煮鱼): Unlike its peers it wasn't presented with a million chili peppers on top. It was good but not outstanding. However, it's offered at a special price of 6 pounds! Dare I say it's about the cheapest, biggest dish you can get in London. - Braised pork belly (红烧肉):  Surprisingly delicious! Sweet, tender, a bit fatty, just the way I like it. Great contrast with all the spicy dishes we had. Veggies were pretty good and reasonably priced too. The service was very friendly and accommodating. I wasn't sure about the size of our party in the beginning but they managed to seat all of us with last minute changes. The menus were extensive and well presented, and I saw them cleaning each menu after being used. I'll definitely go back!

photos.caption: Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Revolution is a dinner party?
Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom

SQVLgOPxbrw9DcD77gaTGQ.text: Worst Chinese restaurant ever The waitress treats customers horribly So was the cashier Food was extremely salty and portion is very little compared with the price we paid I will never come here again 服務超差，不要被騙了東西不好吃又貴

Xwfxv3-fMkcqGDYRumhaDA.text: BarShu's waiting team moved in, however the service was rough and even rude. I felt cultural difference when Malaysian waiting team try to emphasis on the 'efficiency' without considering the comfort of customers. It makes it another cheap 'China town' restaurant. I do want to mention about the food - fish pot and pancake. Well, see picture for yourself, pure dark sauce completely disgusting. Full stop.

photos.caption: Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Baiwei - London, United Kingdom. Fish pot with pancake, can chef cook?!

B8wmSSqVMWIRkDQMB7sKUw.text: This place is disgusting. MSG overload. My mouth is still tingling.Whatever you do DO NOT EAT HERE. I'm used to Chinese waiters not giving you the time of day so I didn't mind he poor service, but the food was totally inexcusable. Like sick to our stomach bad. I can't even describe how bad everything is. I would have paid them not to eat that.Really really really disgusting. Do not go

yUvzJdoLepCq4m4Xl_B-Kg.text: From the same chain as bar shu, another great sichuan restaurant.  This one is cheaper and less formal than bar shu, and the service is warmer (that's not difficult).  The mapo tofu is very good. The tables are very small and close together.
